content: The Act is titled the "Russian-American Trust and Cooperation Act of 2000". It includes findings related to the Act. The Congress finds that the Russian Federation operates an intelligence facility in Cuba, which has raised concerns about espionage activities directed against the United States. The Russian Federation operates an intelligence facility at Lourdes, Cuba, leased for $100-300 million annually. It is the largest complex outside the former Soviet Union, covering 28 square miles. The Lourdes facility in Cuba, operated by the Russian Federation, covers a 28 square-mile area with over 1,500 personnel. It has multiple tracking dishes and a satellite system used for intercepting communications. The Lourdes facility in Cuba, operated by the Russian Federation, has over 1,500 personnel working at the base. It has tracking dishes and a satellite system used for intercepting communications, including telephone calls, faxes, and computer communications. The base has obtained sensitive information about United States military operations. The Lourdes facility in Cuba, operated by the Russian Federation, intercepts telephone calls, faxes, and computer communications. The predecessor regime obtained sensitive information about US military operations during Operation Desert Storm. Academic studies highlight the threat posed by the Lourdes espionage station, collecting personal information about the US. The Lourdes facility in Cuba, operated by the Russian Federation, collects personal information about US citizens in private and government sectors and has the means to engage in cyberwarfare against the United States. The facility's operational significance has increased since February 7, 1996. The Lourdes facility in Cuba, operated by the Russian Federation, collects personal information about US citizens in private and government sectors. The facility has the means to engage in cyberwarfare against the United States. The operational significance of the facility has grown dramatically since February 7, 1996, with the Russian government estimated to have spent over $3 billion on its operation and modernization. The Russian government has spent over $3 billion on the operation and modernization of the Lourdes facility in Cuba, which collects US economic and trade secrets. Former US officials confirm the facility's expansion and upgrade. Former US officials confirm reports of Russian Federation's expansion and upgrade of the Lourdes facility in Cuba, visited by a high-ranking Russian military delegation in December 1999. Prohibition on bilateral debt rescheduling and forgiveness for the Russian Federation. The President is prohibited from rescheduling or forgiving any outstanding bilateral debt owed by the Government of the Russian Federation until certifying to Congress that Russia has ceased all operations. The Paris Club of official creditors will oppose debt rescheduling or forgiveness for Russia until the President certifies that Russia has closed the intelligence facility at Lourdes, Cuba. The President can waive this requirement with a 10-day notice. The Russian Federation has closed its intelligence facility at Lourdes, Cuba. The President can waive this requirement with a 10-day notice if it is in the national interests of the United States. The President can waive the requirement to close the intelligence facility at Lourdes, Cuba if it is in the national interests of the United States, with a detailed description of the supporting facts. The President may waive the closure of the intelligence facility at Lourdes, Cuba if it serves the national interests, with a detailed description of supporting facts. The written certification may be submitted in classified form if deemed appropriate. Periodic reports are required every 180 days after the initial certification transmission. The President may waive closure of the intelligence facility at Lourdes, Cuba if it serves national interests, with supporting facts. Written certification can be submitted in classified form if deemed appropriate. Periodic reports are required every 180 days after initial certification transmission to the relevant committees. SEC. 4. REPORT ON THE CLOSING OF THE INTELLIGENCE FACILITY AT LOURDES, CUBA. The President must submit a report every 120 days detailing Russia's actions to close the intelligence facility in Lourdes, Cuba to specific committees in Congress. The Senate Select Committee on Intelligence requires a report on Russia's actions to close the intelligence facility in Lourdes, Cuba, and the verification efforts by relevant Federal departments or agencies.
